climbs.name: The Berger
climbs.fa: Rob Owens and Roger Strong, January 2007

content.description: A stellar M8+ route that starts in the obvious seem on the right of the hanging ice above. Pull through two powerful bulges to gain delicate face moves and blobs of ice to join The Unknown route at it's 5th bolt (8 bolts total to the ice). Found between Hooker and Candlestick Maker, this is the right of the two bolted lines that go up to the ice for when Candle in the Wind is not fully formed. Standard ice rack for the ice plus 8 quick draws for bolts.

climbs.name: Candle in the Wind
climbs.fa: Andrew Abel and Mikael Williams, Nov 4th, 2018

content.description:
Candle in the Wind rarely forms completely, there is a bolted mixed line to its right called The Berger for when the ice is not touching down.

It is the pillar found between Hooker and Candle Stick Maker.

Climb a steep pillar followed by easier ice up top.

Rappel to descend.

Follow approach for Orient Point and either climb Hidden Dragon or by pass it to the left and scramble up to the base of Candle in the Wind.
Standard ice rack.

A unique climb that can be easy for the grade in good conditions, makes for a fun outing when combined with other climbs in Orient Point. P1 (WI5, 15m of climbing, 35m of snow) - Climb a steep 10m pillar to an easier step of ice above followed by a long snowledge to the base of the next pitch, set up an ice anchor in a sheltered spot. P2 (WI5, 35m of climbing, 35 m of snow ) - Climb varied, featured ice that kicks up in angle near the top and either set up a v thread at the top, or if you have 70s walk 35m up the snowslope to a cluster of trees where you can set up a tree belay. Note that 60m will absolutely not make it. Two rappels to descend. There are a number of bolted mixed variations for when the ice isn't fully formed. Green Dragon, M7-, WI4, 35m (Eric Dumerac and Donald Otten, 2007) is a first pitch bolted variation. Matchstick Maker, M5, WI5 (Stephen O’Brien and Cory Richards, 2007) is a second pitch bolted variation climbing the wall to the right. Rueban and Ross Variation, M7, WI5 (Reuben Marsden and Ross Suchy, Dec. 2015) is a first pitch variation climbing up out of the cave on the right to the ice above. Approach is the same as in "Hidden Dragon" and other Orient Point routes. Once at the base of Hidden Dragon climb it and head up and right past it into the hidden alcove/gully that holds Candle Stick Maker.

Belay from the giant cave that is behind the first pitch pillar. Standard ice rack.

A rarely, if ever formed climb. First seen in early October of 2019. Climbed a few days after forming. It did not last 2 weeks. 

P1: Climb a run out pitch of thin ice & featured slab for 50m. WI3R, M4. We managed to place a tied off stubby & one micronut on this pitch. Belay off ice behind crux pillar.
P2: Climb a 35m series of pillars and vertical ice to a solid belay stance. Belay off thin ice. WI4.
P3: Good rock & thin ice takes you to a tree belay on the left. 50m.

Walk over to CSM & rappel as for CSM.

Located 100 meters climber's right of Candlestick maker. 
Ice screws, small rock rack, valium, diapers.

Hidden Dragon is the climb at the bottom of the Orient Point cirque and is often used as the approach climb to access the upper routes. A wide curtain of ice that can vary greatly in conditions and length depending on how much snow is present. Either climb the steep left side for 15-30 meters to lower angle ice that can run all the way up to the upper climbs, or climb the right side for 60 meters through a series of steps to a 2 pin and 1 tree belay on the right. From the Big Hill turn south down the riverbed following a road that may or may not be obvious, drive past a berm on your right and small hill directly on your right. Keep heading south until you see an obvious cutline road going steeply up into Orient Point directly West. If it's early season and you have a monster truck, you might be able to drive up the cutline a ways (there are places to park and turn around) otherwise park here.

Follow the cut line to its end, then trend left and traverse along the hillside for as far as you can before dropping down into the gully. Once you are in the gully follow it straight up to the base of Hidden Dragon. Standard ice rack.

climbs.name: Hooker
climbs.fa: Joe Josephson and Ken Wylie, Dec 1992

content.description:
A rarely formed pillar to the right of the Joker.

55m of rambling ice gets you to a sheltered belay to the left of the pillar.

Fire up the crux pillar for 30 meters to easier ice above and a couple more pitches.

Rappel the route.

Immediately right of the Joker, an obvious pillar when formed.
Standard ice rack.

A classic early season former with ice up to 75 degrees.

The obvious low angle route on the left side of the bowl.
Screws (generally short in early season). Two bolt chain anchor and a pin at the top. Rap the route.

climbs.name: Real Big Drip
climbs.fa: Dave Thomson, Sean Isaac, Eric Dumerac and Kefira Allen

content.description:
A magnificent line that you can't miss as you drive into the Ghost. It seems to form up every year, but with subtle differences, usually to the first ice pitch. Note: The lower ice on the first pitch occasionally falls down, so if the ice isn't hanging nearly to the lowest prominent roof, don't bother with the route. The bolts will end before you can get to the ice. Pitch 1, 30m, M8 (bolted). Overhanging for all but the first 5m, it has gotten harder as features have broken off. Finding good holds is difficult and strenuous, and it seems that when the tools are good the feet are bad, and vice versa. There are, however, some bomber holds every few meters where you can catch your breath and shake out. Belay off ice or a bolted station depending on how the ice is formed. Pitch 2 , 40m, WI5/6. A great ice pitch that comes in differently from year to year. Some years it is straightforward, other years it can sport some big overhangs. Climb to a bolted station at the top of the ice Pitch 3, 40m, M7+ (bolted). Starts up left of the bolted station, works through a small overhang (crux) and then traverses up and right on cool rock features to a bolted belay behind the ice curtain. Pitch 4, 35m, WI5+. Makes an exciting transition onto the ice curtain and then up to the ice ramp above. Pitch 5, 50m, WI5. A long pitch of steep ice. From the bottom of the Big Hill, cross the flats to a well defined road that takes you straight south to Orient Point, and a track that follows a cut-line steeply up the hill to the right. Park here.

Hike up the track for 10-15 minutes to an obvious flat, clearing on the right. Continue about 100 m and look for a well defined (horse?) trail heading left. There are a couple small burned-trunk aspens to the left of the trail and a bigger one with a (+) blazed on it to the right (see photo). Follow the trail through the forest and down into the Joker/Hooker drainage. Continue up the streambed a couple hundred meters, then go left at the intersection of the RBD drainage. It’s best to hike the banks of the drainage as much as possible, crossing it several times. When the drainage ends, work your way up and slightly left through some sketchy rock bands to the route. (Note: when hiking out, definitely easier and safer to rappel the rock bands).

Anywhere from 1.5 to 3 hours, depending on snow conditions. Both rock pitches are bolted, as are the belay stations. Take 15 draws as well as some long runners, along with 12-15 screws. 70m ropes will get you down in three rappels, stay to the climbers left. First rappel from the top (v-thread) of the ice to the ramp. Second (v-thread) goes to the bolts at the top of pitch 2. Third to the ground. Use caution when passing hanging daggers.

The bolted mixed line on the left side of Candle in the Wind. Can be used to access the ice above when Candle in the Wind does not touch down.

Starts with an easy but thin vertical ice smear for 3 meters, then a crux leaving the bench
after that to pass the 2nd bolt. Grade 4 ice to finish to a V-thread.

Standard ice rack.

Just south of Devil's Gap is Orient Point, containing a good number of early season routes including The Joker which is often a season opener. Access early in the season is easy, as snow accumulates it becomes harder.
